title: medicine - Wiktionary, the free dictionary
cleaned_text: medicine [Jump to shop, a remedy, medicine"), feminine of [medicnus](/wiki/medicinus#Latin) ("of or belonging to physic or surgery, or to a physician or surgeon"), from [medicus](/wiki/medicus#Latin) ("a physician, surgeon"). The extended cognates some way; a [pharmaceutical](/wiki/pharmaceutical) [drug](/wiki/drug). - This medicine has fewer adverse effects than others in its drug class. - Using a weekly pill organizer is a good way to help remind yourself to take your medicine each day, and it also tells you whether you already took today's pills (it's not unusual to forget doing a habitual task)! - Synonym: [medication](/wiki/medication#English) [treatment](/wiki/treatment)or [cure](/wiki/cure). - A legislative remedy might be some harsh medicine; is that cure worse than the ill? - 1625, [Francis Bacon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Bacon), Of Innovation: - Surely every medicine is an innovation; and he that will not apply new remedies, must expect new evils [...] - ( [uncountable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#uncountable)) The study of the cause, [diagnosis](/wiki/diagnosis), [prognosis](/wiki/prognosis)and [treatment](/wiki/treatment)of [disease](/wiki/disease)or [illness](/wiki/illness). - She's studying medicine at university because she wants to be a doctor in the future. - ( [uncountable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#uncountable)) The [profession](/wiki/profession)and [practice](/wiki/practice)of [physicians](/wiki/physician), including [surgeons](/wiki/surgeon). - The history of medicine can be discretized into eras with differing relationships between physicians and surgeons - Hypernyms: [health care](/wiki/health_care#English), [healthcare](/wiki/healthcare#English) nonsurgical [physicians](/wiki/physician)as sometimes distinguished from that of [surgeons](/wiki/surgeon). - the evolving relationship of medicine to surgery in the nineteenth century - Coordinate term: [surgery](/wiki/surgery#English) - - - ( [uncountable](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#uncountable)) Ritual [magic](/wiki/magic)used, as by a [medicine man](/wiki/medicine_man), to promote a desired outcome in healing, hunting, or warfare; [traditional medicine](/wiki/traditional_medicine). - Among the Native Americans, any [object](/wiki/object)supposed to give control over natural or magical forces, to act as a protective charm, or to cause healing. - 1896, F. H. Giddings, The Principles of Sociology: - The North American Indian boy usually took as his medicine the first animal of which he dreamed during the long and solitary fast that he observed at puberty. - ( [obsolete](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#obsolete)) [Black magic](/wiki/black_magic), IV, Part I](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_First_Part_of_King_Henry_the_Fourth#Scene_II._The_Road_by_Gads-hill.), II. ii. 18: - If the rascal have not given me medicines to make me love him, I'll be hanged. It could not be else. I have drunk medicines. - ( [obsolete](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#obsolete)) A [physician](/wiki/physician). - 1598, Ends Well](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/All%27s_Well_That_Ends_Well), II. i. 72: - I have seen a medicine / That's able to breathe life into a stone - ( Hyponyms[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=medicine&action=edit§ion=7)] [academic medicine](/w/index.php?title=academic_medicine&action=edit&redlink=1)(which entails clinical medicine, medical education, biomedical basic science, and biomedical applied science) [clinical medicine](/wiki/clinical_medicine#English)(comprising all point of care activity) [laboratory medicine](/w/index.php?title=laboratory_medicine&action=edit&redlink=1)(which entails many lab tests, such as most serology and most NAATs (e.g., most go down](/wiki/a_spoonful_of_sugar_helps_the_medicine_go_down#English) [a spoonful of sugar makes past participle [medicined](/wiki/medicined#English)) [obsolete](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#obsolete)) To treat with medicine. - 1857, Delia Bacon, The philosophy of the plays of Shakspere unfolded: - And we shall find, under the head of the medicining of the body, some things on the subject of medicine in general, which could be better said there than here, because of the wrath of professional dignitaries,- the eye of the 'basilisk,' was not perhaps quite so terrible in that quarter then, as it was in some others.
